titleInfo.title: Novel Methods and Applications to Identify Risk Genes and Image-Derived Phenotypes for Alzheimer's Disease

mods:mods.abstract: The genetic architecture of Alzheimer's disease is largely unknown. Imaging-wide association study (IWAS) that integrates brain imaging information with genome-wide association studies (GWAS) results have successfully enhanced the discovery of genetic risk loci for late-onset Alzheimer's disease (AD). However, IWAS requires an individual-level reference panel that has matched brain imaging and genetic data. This reference panel can be limited in sample size and hard to acquire, which creates a challenge for IWAS. Here, we propose an integrative analysis method that directly integrates an arbitrary number of brain imaging GWAS summary results with the trait of interest GWAS results. As an illustration, we integrated GWAS summary results of several brain volume-related regions of interest from 8,428 individuals in UK Biobank with several late-onset AD GWAS results. For example, when reanalyzing to-date the largest AD GWAS results, our proposed method identified 98 AD-associated genes, 63 of which have been ignored by standard gene-based tests and transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS). On the other hand, the causation between AD and white matter microstructure remains largely unknown, although white matter abnormalities imply an early neuropathological event in Alzheimer's disease. To fill this gap, relying on existing GWAS datasets, we conducted Mendelian Randomization studies to identify the causal relationship between two pairs of phenotypes: 1) Alzheimer's disease and 105 tract-specific principal components for FA (top 5 PCs of FA measures for the 21 white matter tracts) and 2) Alzheimer's disease and 110 tract-average parameters (FA, MD, AD, RD, and MO for 21 white matter tracts and the whole brain average). MR results showed that the genetic responsibility of AD affects the first FA PC in cingulum (hippocampus), first FA PC in fornix-stria terminalis, second FA PC in corticospinal tract, second FA PC in genu of corpus callosum, fourth FA PC in corticospinal tract, mean FA of cingulum (hippocampus), mean FA of fornix-stria terminalis, mean MD of cingulum (hippocampus), mean RD of cingulum (hippocampus), mean AD of fornix-stria terminalis, mean MO of fornix-stria terminalis, and mean MO of fornix (column and body of fornix). In summary, these newly identified genes and brain imaging information provide new insights into the etiology of AD.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Alzheimer's disease, Bidirectional Mendelian randomization, Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), Robust MR, Sum test, Summary IWAS
Chong Wu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Nowakowski, University Representative; Xufeng Niu, Committee Member; Jinfeng Zhang, Committee Member.
